Cigarette smoking produces a variety of detrimental effects which are of special importance for diabetic patients [ 13.

It contributes to increased morbidity and mortality both in type 1 and type 2 diabetes . Stopping smoking reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in younger and older patients, decreases the incidence of strokes and reduces the risk of overall vascular morbidity and mortality.
Nevertheless, the prevalence of smokers amongst diabetic patients hardly differs from that of the general population [ 11.
Therefore, effective smoking cessation programmes seem particularly needed for diabetic patients.
In non-diabetic patients, cessation programmes have been reported to have a small, but important, positive effect or may even yield success rates of up to 45% over 1 year.
Minimal physician counselling has also been shown to be effective.

However, in diabetic patients even elaborate cess-27 ation programmes seem to be without any effect This study was designed to compare the effectiveness of a extensive behavioural anti-smoking programme with a physician's short session of antismoking advice.
From a diabetes department clinic, 2674 patients were asked about their smoking habits.
Out of this group 13% of type 2 diabetic patients and 29% of type 1 diabetic patients reported regular smoking of more than 5 cigarettes per day.
A total of 794 patients who were living within 100 km of the investigation centre were invited by mail to participate in a 'stop-smoking programme'.
Out of this group 89 patients (1 1 %) agreed to participate and were randomized into an intervention group ( n = 44) and a control group ( n = 45).

behaviour therapy anti-smoking programme supervised by a specially educated psychotherapist.
This programme consists of 10 weekly sessions of 90 min each and aims at self-controlled reduction in nicotine intake.
The patients are encouraged to gradually decrease their number of cigarettes and stop smoking after the fifth session.

Non-smoking motivation is based on behaviour learning of how to begin cigarette reduction, discovering why you want to stop and why you have failed before, learning why you smoke, learning how to continue not to smoke and what support is available.
Relaxation techniques are included in the programme.
This structured behaviour progrmme is being used widely as a smoking cessation intervention in Germany and has been extensively described elsewhere [ 141.
The control group was to receive an unstructured nonsmoking advice session of about 1 5 min given by a physician in the diabetes out-patient clinic of the department.
In case of self-reported 'severe ' tobacco addiction, nicotine replacement (nicotine polacrilex gum) was offered to the patients.
All randomized patients were studied at baseline and re-investigated 6 months after intervention.
No patients were excluded or lost to follow-up.
Nonsmoking was assumed when at the 6 - month visit a patient self-reported not smoking and not using nicotine replacements and serum cotinine was below 20 ng ml-I.
Cotinine was measured in serum by a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) method with the upper value for non-smokers being 20 ng ml-'.
Glycosylated haemoglobin values (HbAlc) were measured by an HPLC method, the normal range being 4.4 - 5.5 % of total haemoglobin.
The HbAlc values given in were measured at baseline before participation of the patients in a structured diabetes teaching and treatment programme.
Proteinuria was estimated by laser turbidimetry as described previously, the upper normal range of proteinuria being 6 0 mg 2 4 h-'.
For statistical analysis a two-tailed Student's t-test was performed, P-values below 0.05 were regarded as statistically significant.
In the group of 44 patients randomized into the behaviour therapy group, 2 5 (5 7%) participated in the programme.
Of the control group 3 1 patients (69 %) visited the out-patient clinic fora physician's anti-smoking advice.

During the behaviour therapy intervention the self-reported mean number of cigarettes smoked was reduced, being 2 1 cigarettes per day per patient (range: 5 4 0 cigarettes per day per patient) at the beginning of the programme and 5 cigarettes per day per patient (range: 0 - 17 cigarettes/day/patient) at the end of the programme.
However, at follow-up after 6 months, only 12 patients reported not smoking anymore (four in the intervention group and eight in the control group).
Of these patients, three had elevated serum cotinine concentrations (21 ng ml-' : 27 ng m1 - l: 101 ng ml-l).
Hence, two patients in the intervention group ( 5 %) and seven patients in the control group (1 6 %) were regarded as confirmed non-smokers at follow-up.
This difference between the groups is not statistically significant.
The results of this study show that smoking is frequent in type 1 and type 2 diabetic patients.
However, few smoking patients with diabetes are willing to participate in a smoking cessation programme.
Every third patient of those who initially stated to be willing to participate in an anti-smoking programme did not attend the meetings at all afterwards.
In diabetic patients willing to stop smoking, a widespread extensive structured behaviour therapy programme was no more effective than a short single session of a physician's advice.
Overall, the results of smoking cessation in both groups are disappointing.
However, approaches other than behaviour therapy techniques might be more effective, a hypothesis which remains to be tested in future controlled investigations.
In contrast to non-diabetic patients who make a serious attempt to stop smoking and amongst whom up to 45% may succeed, diabetic patients are less successful [12, 131.
The reasons for this difference between diabetic and non-diabetic smokers are not clear.
This study was not designed to clarify why the diabetic population maybe different.
However, one possible explanation is that depressive disorders occur more frequently in diabetic patients-when subjects with a history of depression stop smoking depressive symptoms may worsen.

Diabetic patients who, in some cases, are already psychologically adversely affected by the chronic nature of their disease, maybe less willing to accept a further impairment in their subjective perception of wellbeing associated with smoking cessation.
In conclusion, smoking represents an important unsolved problem in the healthcare of diabetic patients.
To date for this group of patients, a doctor's comprehensive anti-smoking advice seems to be more reasonable than the implementation of complex behaviour modification programmes.
